@luz Please send a pull request if you have a propose solution.  Attaching code makes it very difficult to review and provide feedback on code.

@houshengbo Vagrantfile setups the VM with the $PATH to include `/home/vagrant/openwhisk/bin/wsk`    for example in simple here https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tools/vagrant/simple/Vagrantfile#L59
with `sed -i.bak s/:\\\\/bin/:\\\\/bin:\\\\/home\\\\/vagrant\\\\/openwhisk\\\\/bin/g /etc/environment`

isn't it `body[i].config.url`? here is an example record in the array that api.github.com returns:

```
{
    "type": "Repository",
    "id": 8814032,
    "name": "web",
    "active": true,
    "events": [
      "push"
    ],
    "config": {
      "content_type": "json",
      "url": "https://xxx:yyy@openwhisk.ng.bluemix.net/api/v1/namespaces/uitest3_uitest3/triggers/my git trigger"
    },
    "updated_at": "2016-06-19T23:44:40Z",
    "created_at": "2016-06-19T23:44:40Z",
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/testLime/lime/hooks/8814032",
    "test_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/testLime/lime/hooks/8814032/test",
    "ping_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/testLime/lime/hooks/8814032/pings",
    "last_response": {
      "code": 422,
      "status": "misconfigured",
      "message": "Invalid HTTP Response: 403"
    }
  }
```

i also notice that `body[i].config.url` doesn't URL-encode the trigger name. notice that my trigger name has spaces in it... https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/702

also observe the hard-coded use of the YP endpoint, despite me invoking this feed creation on YS1. https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/699
I tried using public ip of host machine, it worked.

do you know why `reduce_limit` is needed? As a rule of thumb, that's an indication of a bad reduce function (reduce functions need to reduce) - Cloudant doesn't allow this to be disabled so it will become a problem there as well but probably requires a larger data volume before the warning is triggered.
@bjustin-ibm hiya, do the parameters have any sensitive information? e.g. does the uri contain passwords?
I've been advised to stay away from any Swift 3 build post May 5.

> does the uri contain passwords

@starpit Like any action parameters, they contain exactly what the caller puts in them, and so it is not generally predictable whether or not they will contain sensitive information. In terms of websockets, I don't believe it is necessarily true that the URI _will_ include authentication information, though I suppose it _could_.
ok cool, thanks for the great summary! does a websocket have any sort of lifecycle, e.g. account registration, credentialing, ...?
Now includes @rabbah's change per @lehoanganh's suggestion.

as much as possible, i think we'd like to avoid the "hey this is tantalizing and sounds cool, but to use it you'll need to do stuff we don't tell you about". 

e.g. mobile developer wants a websocket server, see this... after all, whisk is trying to help people avoid setting up servers!

maybe we can belay this reaction by naming the package or action ... somehow?

@dubeejw - A few questions/comments.
- Should annotations be processed similar to the parameters?  I think both can take JSON
- Regarding the parseParameters() and parseParametersArray() functions - can a single parseParameters() function handle the parsing such that the command handler is not entirely aware of the parameter value format?
- Why is a '+' (plus) character replaced with a ' ' (space) character in the action name, package name, rule name, and trigger name after the name is URL escaped?  I see that the url.QueryUnescape() does the inverse of ur.QueryEscape(), but it converts '+' to ' ' (space).
The views that are computed perform maps, not reductions - we precompute views that allow queries by date, namespace, and action name.
@vmtyler This should be fix now, give it a try
Replaced with #709.
LGTM

@mdeuser,

url.QueryEspace replace spaces with plus characters. In comparison, the Python CLI never replaces spaces for the action, package, rule, and trigger names. Replacing the plus characters with spaces is needed in the Go CLI to achieve parity with the Python CLI. Also, if the spaces are not preserved, automated tests fail.
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/688 is merged. Issue closed.

@rabbah : we can refactor, however it was the original idea where shared stuff is placed in central, cloudant and couchdb use the things as dependency like every programmer will do (place common stuff in functions). Afterwards we decided to make each role like cloudant, couchdb to self-contained, so that one can use each role independently (don't have to import another roles). That's why for now, cloudant and couchdb have redundany

My suggestion is, take the couchdb as example and write the new one for the own couchdb

@rabbah in that case, disabling reduce_limit should not be required. Looking at the views in the repository, https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/d19d9de7df07cc4e69c2c47dc7c29a903ec6bba8/tools/db/loadTransientDBViews.sh#L60 appears to be the offending reduce function. I suggest that instead of using a reduce, this is pulled out as a separate map function (e.g. packages-public), or a compound key used.

In order to future-proof the value for the Node 0.12.x `kind`, I suggest it be "node:0.12" as opposed to "node:12".

@lehoanganh @domdom82 Please review the commit above (https://github.com/psuter/openwhisk/commit/7f8acd7def29f99d75de204fecd1a1e2ed6c8df4). The ansible roles for kafka and zookeeper were not correct and did not preserve the semantics of [isAlive](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tools/health/isAlive). This caused some combination of zookeeper/kafka misconfiguration that surfaces in the invoker with the symptom described above. This symptom seems to resolve itself after several minutes. We have not yet completely explained the issue but restoring `isAlive` semantics is important.

The reason this symptom does not surface in Travis CI or local tests (unless you repeat the steps outlined above) is that there are several minutes worth of tests that run before the first test that required the invoker to be involved.

All roles should be checked for semantic equivalence with `isAlive`. @psuter and I fixed the two immediate ones that are impacting/blocking work related to streaming db support (needed for zip file uploads and the like). You should verify the other components are not equally giving false positive "is alive" responses.

`consul` alive check is affected by this as well - possibly others. I defer to you to investigate further.

FYI @jeremiaswerner
@domdom82 @lehoanganh please review.

@csantanapr, correct.

I think we need to wait to see what can be consolidated and refactor.

For now I would suggest to

1 Re-use the file name `catalog/installCatalog.sh`  (making the change transparent to anything executing this file today)
The new content will be something like 

```
git clone https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-catalog
cd  openwhisk-catalog
./install.sh
```

2 Move the contents of `catalog/installCatalog.sh` into new `openwhisk-catalog/install.sh`
@dubeejw I will wait before I merge for a green Travis build on the commit https://travis-ci.org/openwhisk/openwhisk/builds/139308715
Note that this is a breaking API change as existing actions might stop working when run in nodejs 6.

```
TASK [kafka : wait until the Kafka in this host is up and running] *************
Tuesday 21 June 2016  22:27:43 +0200 (0:00:01.511)       0:01:09.543 **********
FAILED - RETRYING: TASK: kafka : wait until the Kafka in this host is up and running (11 retries left).
ok: [192.168.120.130]
```

What should happen after 12 retrries and the until condition is still not met? It's a non-zero return code and ansible stops?
kafka should be considered not responsive and deployment halted.
@mdeuser, please review.
@dubeejw - I can take a look, but we should have one of the ansible experts eyes on this as well.

@lfzCarlosC I don't use vagrant. I use a Ubuntu VM with a CouchDB installed in the same VM. I don't know if it is similar.

When I type command: `ifconfig`, I will see three network interfaces and three IP address:
docker0 172.17.0.1
eth0 10.0.2.15
lo 127.0.0.1

I choose the IP address of `eth0` as the database IP in the database configuration file, i.e. 10.0.2.15.
I don't know if that is helpful. If you can explain the detail of your network, I can see if I can help.

The `webhook.js` has been written to use as feed and not as action.
When you use it as feed, `params.triggerName` is set implicitly. So it is not required, on executing the action as feed.
But I agree, that the parameter is required, if you want to use it as action.
